p: In this study, it was established that diabetic untreated group (Figures 1 – 3) showed a statistically significant decrease ( p < 0.05) in CAT (10.8 ± 0.6 u/mg), SOD (12.8 ± 0.2 u/mg), and GPx (0.48 ± 0.6 nmol/mg) activities compared to normal rats without treatment. Diabetic rats treated with A. conyzoides significantly increased ( p < 0.05) in cardiac CAT (36.4 ± 1.1 to 38.2 ± 1.3 u/mg), SOD (38.2 ± 1.2 to 40.8 ± 1.4 u/mg), and GPx (0.96 ± 0.5 to 0.97 ± 0.4 nmol/mg) activities (Figures 1 – 3) compared to the diabetic untreated animals, along the same line. However, a significant decrease ( p < 0.05) in MDA content (4.4 ± 0.6 nmol/mg) ( Figure 4) was observed in the diabetic untreated group when compared to the normal animals. Diabetic treated group with the A. conyzoides, however, significantly reduced the MDA (1.48 ± 0.2 to 1.47 ± 0.4 nmol/mg) ( Figure 4) compared to the diabetic group.
